pullRequest.body:
Example usage:

```
example (xs ys : List α) : (xs ++ ys ++ ys).length = 2 * ys.length + xs.length := by
  rw_search  -- Try this: rw [@List.length_append, @List.length_append, @add_rotate, Nat.two_mul]
```

---

Thank you very much, @Vierkantor, for the review! I'll get to it soon. I hope this means the polishing is going well. :-)

> I hope this means the polishing is going well. :-)

It's certainly converging quickly enough that I'm allowing myself some time to do other things again :D

Note: I have pushed an update to the lean toolchain because this PR was on a [buggy version](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113488-general/topic/Potential.20data.20loss.20from.20.60lake.20clean.60.20with.204.2E2.2E0-rc2.2F3/near/397875701) of the toolchain. **WARNING**: checking out old commits of this PR using v4.2.0-rc2 or v4.2.0-rc3 can cause `lake clean` to delete your mathlib folder! If you need to do so, make sure to delete `lakefile.olean` manually before running any `lake` commands.

:v: semorrison can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge
@semorrison just to confirm, you saw the build failure in your last commit before you accepted the suggestions and merged, right?

> @semorrison just to confirm, you saw the build failure in your last commit before you accepted the suggestions and merged, right?

Yes. There was a build failure after I merged master, which I've fixed (changes to `DiscrTree` tree API).

Nice work! I'll have to delegate the MetaM part to someone else but the normal functional program looks good.

This has been held up long enough. @semorrison if you're happy with the current state, let's merge and see how it does in practice.

bors d+
Nice work! I'll have to delegate the MetaM part to someone else but the normal functional program looks good.

This has been held up long enough. @semorrison if you're happy with the current state, let's merge and see how it does in practice.

bors d+
Is this still accurate once #6764 lands?

```suggestion
The `rw_search` tactic will rewrite by local hypotheses,
but will not use local hypotheses to discharge side conditions. 
This limitation would need to be resolved in the `rw?` tactic first.
```
Thanks! I will add a test for this.

I like sorted imports :)
```suggestion
import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Preimage
import Mathlib.Data.Prod.Lex
import Mathlib.Order.Estimator
```

One thing I'm noticing is that the control flow is quite deeply nested. If we weren't already in a monadic context, many `match` statements on `Option`s could be replaced with binds:
```
  match s.next? with
  | none => pure none
  | some ((n, l), s') => ...
```
could morally become:
```
  let ((n, l), s') ← s.next?
```
Maybe there is still a way to do this with Lean's fancier `do`?

This also reappears a few times below.

Regardless of monadology, how about moving the logic that improves the estimate for the queue's head to a separate definition? I imagine it could also be useful in other applications (for example, peek).
I didn't have any luck with the monadology, but the refactoring suggestion was a great improvement. I've also added lots of comments explaining the flow control.

Do I understand correctly that we can also see this as a priority queue mapping `a : α` to `b : β`, with `a` allowed to occur multiple times? This way, we can also interpret the use of the `MLList` as an optimization so multiply occurring keys don't need to have their priority recalculated.

Well, it's also so we don't actually have to calculate the whole list in advance until it is needed.

(Moreover, even after we calculate some initial segment of an MLList, because it is lowest priority, something else could arrive at the head of the queue, obviating the need to calculate more of the list.)
I've added some further explanation here.

In this context of best-first search, I initially interpreted lower priorities to mean worse, but here they are better, right? (This order on priority goes against the conventions in Lean where lower priorities are visited later, maybe we should replace "priority" with another word?)
```suggestion
so we instead keep track of a lower bound (where less is better) for each such `a : α`.
```

```suggestion
and pulling off terminal `)`, `]`, or `,` characters. -/
```
Should this instead be in a `test` file?
Moved!
What exactly does "work better" mean here? Do you mean `rw_search` returns better results, or returns the same results more efficiently?
Added some further discussion.

This concatenation operation means this function is quadratic in the number of split postfix delimiters. Of course profiling should be used first, but an accumulating parameter might give a relatively easy performance win.

Haha. I suspect in practice we see very few words ending in excessively many`)],` characters, but sure.

I couldn't resist asking GPT to do this for me, because I knew this was right up its alley, but the Lean 4 knowledge would probably be hard for it. It probably took longer than writing it myself, but GPT [managed with some feedback](https://chat.openai.com/share/7457a858-0ff1-4ef3-9c00-ad7447d0b8ae). Just add some nice VSCode integration and voice recognition...?

```suggestion
/-- The cartesian product of two thunks. -/
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
Authors: Scott Morrison
```

```suggestion
/-- The priority function for search is Levenshtein distance plus a penalty. -/
```


this looks mistaken

```suggestion
/-- A node in a `BestFirstQueue`. -/
```
